etymologies: early 16th century; earliest use found in John Irland (c1440–1495), theologian. From Middle French pravité and its etymon classical Latin prāvitās crookedness, distortion, perverseness, depravity from prāvus + -tās

definitions: Moral perversion or corruption; wickedness, depravity; an instance of this.

notes.text: "†original (also natural) pravity" (Theology): the innate corruption of human nature due to original sin (obsolete).
